A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
Does the concept of a/an Map/Function need to be defined for a definition of a/an Dihedral Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To understand the dihedral group $D_n$, it is essential to comprehend the concept of permutations, which are specific types of functions or maps. In the definition of $D_n$, the group is generated by permutations $\(\sigma\)$ and $\(	au\)$. These permutations are functions that map elements of the set $\(\{1, 2, ..., n\}\)$ to other elements within the same set, adhering to certain rules (in this case, representing rotations and reflections of the vertices of an $n$-gon).

A map or function, by definition, is a relationship that associates every element of one set (domain) to exactly one element of another set (codomain). In the context of the dihedral group, $\(\sigma\)$ and $\(	au\)$ are such maps, as they each take every vertex of the $n$-gon (elements of their domain) and associate them uniquely to other vertices (elements of their codomain).

Therefore, understanding the concept of a map or function is crucial for defining the dihedral group, as the operations that generate the group are themselves maps. Without the concept of a map or function, the definition of permutations and thus the structure of the dihedral group would not be comprehensible.
